awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Preferences and Equilibrium in Laboratory Financial Markets
awd_abstract_narration:
General Equilibrium (GE) theory is the mathematical framework that economists use to understand how markets generate prices and distribute resources within a society. However, GE is impossible to directly test in the field because a primary input, the preferences of individuals, is private information not known to outside analysts. Working in the laboratory over several decades, some economists have instead tested aspects of GE theory by inducing artificial preferences. In parallel, another group of economists has studied how to measure the actual preferences of individuals, using a different body of theory called 'Revealed Preferences' that infers individual preferences from choices made in the face of varying prices and income levels. 
Remarkably, these two poles of economic research have never been brought together empirically and studied jointly: economists have not systematically investigated whether revealed preferences lead to the market outcomes predicted under GE. Our research will begin to fill this gap through a series of new experiments. This research will give us new insight into the predictive power of GE theory and a new, deeper insight into the functioning of interconnected markets, especially financial markets.
Our first project begins with a slight variation on a prominent revealed preference approach to portfolio choice. Subsequent projects incrementally transform simple preference elicitation into state-of-the-art market trading institutions. Individual decision-making tasks are gradually transformed into full-blown interactive markets, but the mechanics of making choices remains nearly identical throughout, allowing us to reliably compare behavior across settings. A suite of new software tools, called Edgeworks, will implement the entire sequence in a unified visual framework. This research will give insight into the efficiency and stability of interdependent (multi-good) markets, especially important aspects of financial markets. It will also help reveal the robustness of elicited preferences in the face of market experience, including recently controversial aspects such as small stakes risk aversion and reference dependence.

por.por_cntn:
This project was designed to improve scientific understanding of how participants’ individual preferencesaffect the performance of markets. With support from this grant, we developed interactive software,described below, that allows human subjects to reveal their preferences over affordable combinations ofgoods (or financial assets) by using a graphical point-and-click interface. Additional software registers thesechoices as orders placed in the market or financial exchange. The grant directly funded a series oflaboratory experiments using this software, and supported numerous students who helped implement thesoftware, conduct the experiments and analyze the data.

We developed three distinct pieces of software through this grant: Licit, TTM, and ContMkts. Licit providessubjects with a battery of choice tasks that reveal their preferences over risky monetary prospects. Some ofthese tasks replicate well-known formats while others are new, allowing us to explore how the choice formataffects the preferences human subjects reveal. More specifically, we can present subjects with the samebasic economic choice in different representations, or embed one set of choices within a larger set, to studyhow the representation or set size impacts their choices. This grant has funded three research projects usingLicit; two have been published (in the Journal of the Economic Science Association, and in EconomicInquiry), while the other is a 2018 working paper. All three of these projects involve subjects making choicesrelated to risk and return, and together the projects establish new regularities on how format affects revealedpreferences. For example, we find that revealed preferences show less sensitivity to outcome variabilitywhen the choices are represented graphically, and also when choices are shown simultaneously in logicalorder.

The TTM software modifies the “Budget Line” task within Licit, allowing the collective choices of subjects(interpreted naturally as “supply and demand”) to impact the underlying prices, transforming a choiceproblem into a market. In “Budget Line,” subjects observe a negatively-sloped line segment spanning thepositive quadrant of (x,y) coordinate axes, and are asked to choose one point on this line segment by mouseclick. Here x and y are probabilistic cash payments; the subject's choice (x,y) on a budget line indicates shewill receive x units of cash with probability p and y units of cash with probability 1-p. In Licit, the slope of eachbudget line (i.e., the -price of x in terms of y) is determined in advance by the experimenter. In TTM, thechoices subjects make on one budget line collectively determine the slope of the next budget line –- the moretheir collective choices weigh towards x (y), the steeper (flatter) the slope of the next budget line. Thisprocess balances how x and y subjects wish to hold with how many units are actually available in theeconomy. Through this grant, we have written a 2018 working paper (presented at many conferences) inwhich we use the choices subjects make under a sequence of Licit budget lines to predict the final,“balanced” slope of the budget line in a TTM market experiment.

The ContMkts softare enables the experimenter to choose a payoff function that converts any subject's“position” in (x,y) space into dollars. The software visualizes these “induced preferences” for subjects usingheatmaps (i.e., higher payoff regions are represented by warmer colors) and mouseover displays. Thepackage implements a double auction trading institution directly on top of this visualization, so that subjectscan trade with each other in order to reach warmer regions of their respective heatmaps. We add severallayers of point-and-click functionality to the standard double auction order book. The first research projectusing ContMkts will begin in Summer 2018.

Support from this grant has also resulted in five additional research projects that focus on the relationshipbetween risk and markets, but that did not use the new software. Three of these projects were published inleading economics journals (Econometrica, Review of Economic Studies, and Journal of Economic Theory),and the other two are working papers.

Broader impacts include educational opportunities for eleven undergraduates, who gained significantexperience in developing web applications and/or organizing lab experiments. Moreover, the project gave sixgraduate R.A.s research training in experimental economics. Further, the capacities pioneered in oursoftware are being incorporated into a new open source platform, oTree, that promises to be widely used bythe experimental economics community. oTree will use the capacities developed under this grant to enablereal-time market experiments in the lab and beyond. Finally, we believe the results of this research willimprove economists' ability to make predictions about the operation of markets (especially financial markets),and interpret the welfare consequences of market outcomes. Since forecasting and interpreting marketoutcomes are fundamentally important to public policy, we expect our research to have indirect but importantpolicy impact.
